headlines.headline: Watch the moment longest ship visits Portsmouth

items.summary: A sunrise drone video captured the moment Mein Schiff 3 arrived in Portsmouth Harbour carrying 2,000 tourists.

media.title: Watch the moment longest ship visits Portsmouth

synopses.short: Drone captures moment longest ship to visit Portsmouth arrives
synopses.long:
A drone has captured a stunning video of the moment the largest ship to ever enter Portsmouth arrived in the harbour at sunrise.
Mein Schiff 3, which has more than 2,000 German passengers onboard, is 965ft (294m) long - beating the record set by Virgin's 909ft-long (277m) Valiant Lady.
The £291m (€360m) TUI vessel, named after the German for "my ship", arrived from Liverpool at about 05:30 BST.
It has been operational since 2014 and boasts 15 bars and nine restaurants. It has a 1,000-strong crew.
Local photographer Marcin Jedrysiak was among those who got up early to watch the ship arrive. 
 
Follow BBC South on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk.
synopses.medium: A sunrise drone video captured the moment Mein Schiff 3 arrived in Portsmouth Harbour carrying 2,000 tourists.

media.caption: The ship is carrying 2,000 German passengers

headlines.headline: Top deck of bus wrecked in suspected arson attack

items.summary: Passengers have to be quickly evacuated from the double decker in Birmingham.

media.title: Top deck of bus wrecked in suspected arson attack

synopses.short: Top deck of Birmingham bus destroyed in suspected arson attack
synopses.long:
The top deck of a bus has been destroyed in a suspected arson attack in Birmingham.
Firefighters were called to Soho Road in Handsworth at 19:20 BST on Wednesday.
Bus operator National Express West Midlands said its 74 service was "swiftly evacuated" of passengers and nobody was hurt.
synopses.medium: Passengers have to be quickly evacuated from the double decker in Birmingham.

media.caption: Passengers had to be quickly evacuated from the double decker in Birmingham

headlines.headline: 'Changing the way we coach so sport is more fun'

items.summary: A campaign to transform the way children are coached to keep them in sport starts at a BMX club.

media.title: 'Changing the way we coach so sport is more fun'

synopses.short: Peckham BMX: 'Changing the way we coach so kids have more fun'
synopses.long:
Getting children to simply enjoy sport is behind an idea which, it is hoped, could lead to more Olympic medals for Team GB in the future. 
The campaign called Play Their Way, launched by Sport England, aims to champion a playful and fun approach to becoming more physically active.
BBC London visited Peckham BMX club to see how it's going about it.
synopses.medium: A campaign to transform the way children are coached to keep them in sport starts at a BMX club.

media.caption: Peckham BMX: 'Changing the way we coach so kids have more fun'

headlines.headline: 'Butterflies create this smile on a face'

items.summary: The Pearl-bordered Fritillary is being brought back to the Malvern Hills in a push for biodiversity.

media.title: 'Butterflies create this smile on a face'

synopses.short: Volunteers reintroduce rare butterfly to Malvern Hills
synopses.long:
A species of butterfly that disappeared from the Malvern Hills 30 years ago has been reintroduced by a conservationist and his army of volunteers. 

Mel Mason, from the West Midlands branch of Butterfly Conservation, has always been fascinated by the colourful creatures and has spent more than a decade protecting and restoring their habitat.

His latest project is the most ambitious yet as he looks to bring the Pearl-bordered Fritillary back to countryside on the borders of Worcestershire, Herefordshire and Gloucestershire.

A film by Audrey Dias and John Bray
synopses.medium: The Pearl-bordered Fritillary is being brought back to the Malvern Hills in a push for biodiversity.

media.caption: Pearl-bordered Fritillary butterflies back on the Malvern Hills
